Submodules

PyAutoExcel.BaseReader module

Base classes for read engines.

class PyAutoExcel.BaseReader.ReadBook(file: bytes | str | IOBase)

Bases: object

Abstract base class for reading workbook data.

This class defines the structure and required methods for reading data from different types of workbook files. Concrete implementations should provide the specific parsing logic.

Variables:

  • __engine__ – Identifier for the engine used to parse the workbook.

  • __deprecated__ – Information about deprecated features.

  • _datas – A dictionary mapping sheet names to their data.

  • _datas_list – A list of sheet data, indexed by sheet order in the workbook.

  • file_name – The path to the workbook file.

nsheets()

Return the number of sheets in the workbook.

Returns:

The number of sheets.

sheet_by_index(idx: int) → ReadSheet

Return a ReadSheet object for the sheet at the given index.

Parameters:

idx – The index of the sheet (0-based).

Returns:

A ReadSheet object corresponding to the sheet at the given index.

sheet_by_name(name: str) → ReadSheet

Return a ReadSheet object for the sheet with the given name.

Parameters:

name – The name of the sheet.

Returns:

A ReadSheet object corresponding to the sheet with the given name.

sheet_names()

Return a list of all sheet names in the workbook.

Returns:

A list of sheet names.

sheets()

Return a list of ReadSheet objects for all sheets in the workbook.

Returns:

A list of ReadSheet objects.

class PyAutoExcel.BaseReader.ReadSheet(data: list[list], name: str)

Bases: object

A class to wrap parsed worksheet data.

This class is designed to provide a convenient interface to access data from a worksheet. Instances of this class are not meant to be created directly by the user; instead, they are returned by methods of the ReadBook class, such as sheet_by_index and sheet_by_name.

Parameters:

  • data – The raw data of the worksheet as a list of lists.

  • name – The name of the worksheet.

Variables:

  • _data – The raw data of the worksheet stored internally.

  • _translated – The transposed data of the worksheet stored internally.

  • name – The name of the worksheet.

property data

Get a copy of the worksheet data.

Returns:

A copy of the worksheet data as a list of lists.

property ncolumns

Get the number of columns in the worksheet.

Returns:

The number of columns.

property nrows

Get the number of rows in the worksheet.

Returns:

The number of rows.

read_cell(row: int, column: int)

Retrieve the value of a cell at a specified row and column.

Parameters:

  • row – The row number (0-based index) of the cell.

  • column – The column number (0-based index) of the cell.

Returns:

The value of the cell.

read_column(column: int)

Retrieve all values from a specified column.

Parameters:

column – The column number (0-based index) to retrieve.

Returns:

A list of values from the specified column.

read_range(rng: CellRange)

Retrieve all values from a specified range.

Parameters:

rng – The range to retrieve.

Returns:

A list of lists of values from the specified range.

read_row(row: int)

Retrieve all values from a specified row.

Parameters:

row – The row number (0-based index) to retrieve.

Returns:

A list of values from the specified row.

PyAutoExcel.BaseWriter module

Base classes for write engines.

class PyAutoExcel.BaseWriter.ColumnDictGridWriteBook

Bases: WriteBook

A class representing a workbook with a column dictionary grid.

This class inherits from WriteBook and uses a column dictionary grid for storing data.

gcls

alias of ColumnDictGrid

class PyAutoExcel.BaseWriter.ListGridWriteBook

Bases: WriteBook

A class representing a workbook with a list grid.

This class inherits from WriteBook and uses a list grid for storing data.

gcls

alias of ListGrid

class PyAutoExcel.BaseWriter.RecordGridWriteBook

Bases: WriteBook

A class representing a workbook with a record grid.

This class inherits from WriteBook and uses a record grid for storing data.

gcls

alias of RecordGrid

class PyAutoExcel.BaseWriter.WriteBook

Bases: object

Abstract base class for writing workbook data.

Variables:

  • __engine__ – Identifier for the engine used to write the workbook.

  • __deprecated__ – Information about deprecated features.

  • gcls – The grid class to be used for the workbook.

add_sheet(sheet_name: str, index: int = -1)

Add a new sheet to the workbook.

Parameters:

  • sheet_name – The name of the sheet to be added.

  • index – The index at which the sheet should be added.

Returns:

The WriteSheet object representing the added sheet.

gcls = None
get_sheet(name_or_idx: int | str) → WriteSheet

Get a sheet from the workbook by name or index.

Parameters:

name_or_idx – The name or index of the sheet to retrieve.

Returns:

The WriteSheet object representing the retrieved sheet.

save(saver: None | str | BytesIO = None)

Save the workbook data.

Parameters:

saver – The destination to save the workbook data to.

Returns:

The saved workbook data.

abstract save_file(file_name: str)

Abstract method to save the workbook data to a file.

Parameters:

file_name – The name of the file to save the workbook data to.

save_io(file: IOBase)

Save the workbook data to an IO stream.

Parameters:

file – The IO stream to save the workbook data to.

save_virtual()

Save the workbook data to a virtual file and return the data as bytes.

Returns:

The workbook data as bytes.

property sheet_names: list[str]

Get the list of sheet names in the workbook.

Returns:

A list of sheet names in the workbook.

property sheets: list[WriteSheet]

Get the list of sheets in the workbook.

Returns:

A list of WriteSheet objects representing the sheets in the workbook.

class PyAutoExcel.BaseWriter.WriteSheet(sheet_name: str, grid_class=None)

Bases: object

A class representing a single sheet in a workbook.

Parameters:

  • sheet_name – The name of the sheet.

  • grid_class – The grid class to be used for the sheet.

Variables:

  • name – The name of the sheet.

  • records – A list to store records if no grid is provided.

get_grid()

Get the grid object associated with the sheet.

Returns:

The grid object associated with the sheet.

Raises:

AttributeError if the sheet has no grid associated with it.

write_cell(row: int, col: int, value)

Write a value to a cell in the sheet.

Parameters:

  • row – The row index (0-based) of the cell.

  • col – The column index (0-based) of the cell.

  • value – The value to be written to the cell.

write_col(col: int, values: list)

Write a list of values to a column in the sheet.

Parameters:

  • col – The column index (0-based) to write the values.

  • values – A list of values to be written to the column.

write_range(rng: CellRange, content: list[list])

Write a 2D list of values to a range of cells in the sheet.

Parameters:

  • rng – The CellRange object representing the range of cells to write to.

  • content – A 2D list of values to be written to the range.

write_row(row: int, values: list)

Write a list of values to a row in the sheet.

Parameters:

  • row – The row index (0-based) to write the values.

  • values – A list of values to be written to the row.

PyAutoExcel.Cell module

Create a class named “Cell” to represent a cell in an Excel-style spreadsheet. The class should have attributes to store the row and column indices of the cell, as well as methods to set and get the value of the cell. Additionally, implement a method to convert the cell coordinates to a tuple format.

class PyAutoExcel.Cell.Cell(row: int | str | tuple, col: int | None = None)

Bases: object

A class representing a cell in an Excel-style spreadsheet.

to_string()

PyAutoExcel.CellRange module

A class representing a range of cells in an Excel-style spreadsheet.

class PyAutoExcel.CellRange.CellRange(row_start: Cell | str | int | range | slice | tuple[int, int] | tuple[int, int, int, int] | tuple[tuple[int, int], tuple[int, int]], col_start: Cell | str | int | tuple | range | slice | None = None, row_end: int | None = None, col_end: int | None = None)

Bases: object

A class representing a range of cells in an Excel-style spreadsheet.

property area

The number of cells in the range.

property col_count

The number of columns in the range.

property row_count

The number of rows in the range.

property single_cell

True if the range contains a single cell.

Returns:

A string representation of the Range.

PyAutoExcel.Deprecated module

Deprecated class for information on abandoned functions.

class PyAutoExcel.Deprecated.DeprecatedInfo(is_deprecated: bool = False, remove_version: str = '', instead: str = '')

Bases: object

A class to represent deprecated information for an engine.

Parameters:

  • is_deprecated (bool) – Indicates if the engine is deprecated.

  • remove_version (str) – The version in which the engine will be removed.

  • instead (str) – Suggested alternative for the deprecated engine.

show(engine: str)

Prints a deprecation warning message for the specified engine.

Parameters:

engine (str) – The name of the deprecated engine.

class PyAutoExcel.Deprecated.DeprecatedMeta

Bases: type

Metaclass for handling deprecated classes.

class PyAutoExcel.Deprecated.DeprecationMessages

Bases: object

A collection of messages related to deprecation.

static deprecated(name: str, version: str, remove_version: str) → str

Generate a deprecation message for a named element.

Parameters:

  • name – The name of the deprecated element.

  • version – The version in which the element was deprecated.

  • remove_version – The version in which the element will be removed.

Returns:

The deprecation message.

static deprecated_with_replacement(name: str, version: str, remove_version: str, replacement: str)

Generate a deprecation message for a named element with a replacement.

Parameters:

  • name – The name of the deprecated element.

  • version – The version in which the element was deprecated.

  • remove_version – The version in which the element will be removed.

  • replacement – The replacement for the deprecated element.

Returns:

The deprecation message with replacement information.

PyAutoExcel.Deprecated.func_deprecated(message: str, warn_id: int)

Decorator for marking a function as deprecated.

Parameters:

  • message – The deprecation message.

  • warn_id – The warning ID.

Returns:

The decorated function.

PyAutoExcel.Deprecated.process_deprecated(info: DeprecatedInfo, name: str)

Checks if the engine is deprecated and displays a warning if so.

Parameters:

  • info (DeprecatedInfo) – A DeprecatedInfo object containing deprecation information about the engine.

  • name (str) – The name of the engine being checked.

PyAutoExcel.Deprecated.set_deprecated_msg(cls: DeprecatedMeta, msg: str, warn_id: int)

Set the deprecated message for a class.

Parameters:

  • warn_id – The type ID of the warning.

  • cls – The class that is being deprecated.

  • msg – The message to display when the class is used.

PyAutoExcel.ExcelTempFile module

Create temporary excel files.

class PyAutoExcel.ExcelTempFile.TemporanyExcelFile(file_format: str = 'xlsx', sheets: list[Sheet] | None = None, tempdir: str = '', delete_after_use: bool = True)

Bases: object

Represents a temporary Excel file.

Parameters:

  • file_format (str) – The format of the file (e.g., ‘xls’, ‘xlsx’).

  • sheets (list[Sheet], optional) – The worksheet contained in the file, can also be added using add_sheet() after creating objects.

  • tempdir (str) – The directory to store this file. Default to TEMPDIR.

  • delete_after_use (bool) – Whether to delete the file after use.

add_sheet(s: Sheet, index: int = -1)

Add a sheet to the document. If index is -1, the sheet will be added to the end of the list of sheets.

Parameters:

  • s (Sheet) – The sheet to add.

  • index (int) – Index at which to add the sheet (default is -1).

close()

Close the temporany file and destory the document instance. If delete_after_use is True, the file will be deleted.

property nsheets

Return the number of sheets in the workbook.

Returns:

The number of sheets in the workbook.

sheet_by_index(idx: int)

Return a Sheet object for the sheet at the given index.

Parameters:

idx – The index of the sheet (0-based).

Returns:

A Sheet object corresponding to the sheet at the given index.

sheet_by_name(name: str)

Return a Sheet object for the sheet with the given name.

Parameters:

name – The name of the sheet.

Returns:

Bases: object

class PyAutoExcel.ParserInterface.Parser(fields: list[Field])

Bases: object

fill members to object

members: fields -> list of Field object records -> [[fieldname, fieldtype, fieldvalue], …] result -> parsed result object

Nothing

Raises:

Nothing

PyAutoExcel.Utils.to_excel_autowidth_and_border(writer: ExcelWriter, df: DataFrame, sheetname: str, startrow: int, startcol: int)

Write a DataFrame to an Excel sheet and adjust columns’ width based on their content. Additionally, apply a border to all cells.

Parameters:

  • writer (pd.ExcelWriter) – The ExcelWriter object to write the DataFrame into.

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The DataFrame to write to the Excel sheet.

  • sheetname (str) – The name of the sheet where the DataFrame will be written.

  • startrow (int) – The starting row index to write the DataFrame.

  • startcol (int) – The starting column index to write the DataFrame.

This function writes the given DataFrame df to an Excel sheet named sheetname using the provided writer. It automatically adjusts the width of each column based on the maximum length of its content. Additionally, it applies a border to all cells in the DataFrame range.

Returns:

Nothing.
